title: 103_hr3352
content: The "NAFTA Worker Security Act of 1993" establishes the NAFTA Transitional Adjustment Assistance Program under the Trade Act of 1974. This program aims to provide transitional assistance to workers affected by NAFTA. The "NAFTA Worker Security Act of 1993" establishes the NAFTA Transitional Adjustment Assistance Program under the Trade Act of 1974. A group of workers can be certified as eligible for adjustment assistance if a significant number have become separated or are threatened to be separated, and if sales or production have decreased or imports from Mexico or Canada are competitive. The NAFTA Worker Security Act of 1993 establishes the NAFTA Transitional Adjustment Assistance Program under the Trade Act of 1974. Workers can be eligible for adjustment assistance if there is a significant increase in imports from Mexico or Canada that contributed importantly to their separation or threat of separation. The NAFTA Worker Security Act of 1993 establishes the NAFTA Transitional Adjustment Assistance Program under the Trade Act of 1974. The Secretary will issue regulations for applying criteria in making preliminary findings and determinations. Petitions for certification of eligibility can be filed by workers or their union with the State Governor. Upon receipt of a petition, findings and assistance will be provided. Upon receipt of a petition, the Governor will notify the Secretary and make a preliminary finding within 10 days. The petition will be transmitted to the Secretary for further action under subsection (c). The Secretary will review petitions within 30 days to determine eligibility for worker assistance. If criteria are met, a certification will be issued for workers to apply for assistance. Denial of certification is also addressed. Upon denial of certification for a petition, the Secretary will review it to determine if workers may be certified under subchapter A. The certification does not apply to workers separated before January 1, 1994. Workers with certification will receive employment services and training similar to those under subchapter A. The total amount of payments for training under this subchapter between January 1, 1994, and June 30, 1995, shall not exceed $45,000,000. Trade readjustment allowances described in sections 231 through 234 have specific provisions regarding the payment of allowances and worker enrollment in training. A worker must enroll in an approved training program by the 16th week of their initial unemployment benefit period to qualify for trade readjustment allowances. Job search and relocation allowances are also available. The administration of the program follows the same procedures as subchapters A and B, with specific agreements between the Secretary and States outlined in section 239. The procedures for certification and provision of data by the Secretary to assist States in making preliminary findings are specified in section 239. SEC. 3. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends various sections of the Trade Act of 1974 by changing references from "chapter" to "subchapter" and adding a new section on nonduplication of assistance. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends Section 245 of the Trade Act of 1974 to authorize appropriations to the Department of Labor for fiscal years 1994 and 1995 for subchapter D. Terminates assistance under subchapter D after June 30, 1995. The amendments made by sections 2, 3, 4, and 5 will take effect on the date the North American Free Trade Agreement enters into force.
